## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I'm trying to get the most out of my VerusIDs and I have a few questions about advanced features. How do I enable revocation, recovery, and Verus Vault capabilities without setting up a primary identity and at least one revocation/recovery ID?

**AI Assistant:**
I'm happy to help! Unfortunately, you cannot enable revocation, recovery, and Verus Vault capabilities without setting up a primary identity and at least one revocation/recovery ID. It is a requirement to have one primary identity and at least one revocation/recovery ID configured to enable these features. Having these IDs set up is essential for the security and flexibility that VerusIDs provide.

**User:**
That makes sense. I've got another question. Can I spend or access funds immediately after unlocking my VerusID, even if I have a multisig of primary keys?

**AI Assistant:**
No, you cannot spend or access funds immediately after unlocking your VerusID, even if you have a multisig of primary keys. You must first unlock and then wait for the predetermined unlock time before you can spend or access funds. This is a security feature that allows for decentralized recovery of your funds in case of unauthorized access. It's an extra layer of protection to ensure that your assets are safe.

**User:**
That's good to know. One more question: Is Verus Vault only limited to protecting funds and not other digital assets like IDs and NFTs?

**AI Assistant:**
No, Verus Vault is not limited to protecting funds only. It also provides the same level of security for your IDs and NFTs, as well as time locks for other purposes, such as vesting schedules, trusts, and inheritance. So, you can rest assured that all your digital assets are protected with the same level of security and flexibility that VerusIDs offer.
How do I enable revocation, recovery, and Verus Vault capabilities without setting up a primary identity and at least one revocation/recovery ID?

You cannot enable revocation, recovery, and Verus Vault capabilities without setting up a primary identity and at least one revocation/recovery ID. It is a requirement to have one primary identity and at least one revocation/recovery ID configured to enable these features.

IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE THAT ENABLING REVOCATION, RECOVERY, AND ALL VERUS VAULT CAPABILITIES REQUIRE YOU TO HAVE ONE PRIMARY IDENTITY, AND AT LEAST ONE REVOCATION/RECOVERY ID CONFIGURED.A locked VerusID can always be revoked and recovered by its revocation and recovery authority identities, which circumvents the lock. At the same time, anyone with only the primary keys, even a multisig of primary keys must first unlock, then wait for the predetermined unlock time before they can spend or access funds. This gives you, or maybe a company that specializes in watching the blockchain to whom you've assigned the revocation ID to revoke and recover whenever an unauthorized unlock occurs. That means that like a bank, setting a 24 hour unlock delay on your locked IDs actually provides the first decentralized solution to the infamous 5 dollar wrench attack.In addition to a new level of blockchain protection and decentralized funds recovery, Verus Vault provides the same security for your IDs and NFTs as well as time locks for other purposes, such as vesting schedules, trusts, and inheritance. With Verus Vault, you can now protect and recover your funds, preserving all your assets and generational blockchain wealth from common forms of crypto loss or theft, no bank required.#### New Verus Multicurrency, Multichain, DeFi Enabled Testnet
With an easy GUI for basic operations or command line for more advanced functions. Without any programming, you can now create new identities, currencies, liquidity pools, and blockchains for your business, your government, your projects, a worthy cause, your family, or your next decentralized application suite. Send currencies worldwide on the same chain, or across blockchains with ease. Even convert currencies to others on the network without an exchange by sending to yourself and converting along the way.
